1.verse: During David's reign there was a famine for three successive years. David had recourse to the LORD, who said, "There is bloodguilt on Saul and his family because he put the Gibeonites to death."

2.verse: So the king called the Gibeonites and spoke to them. (Now the Gibeonites were not Israelites, but survivors of the Amorites; and although the Israelites had given them their oath, Saul had attempted to kill them off in his zeal for the men of Israel and Judah.)

3.verse: David said to the Gibeonites, "What must I do for you and how must I make atonement, that you may bless the inheritance of the LORD?"

4.verse: The Gibeonites answered him, "We have no claim against Saul and his house for silver or gold, nor is it our place to put any man to death in Israel." Then he said, "I will do for you whatever you propose."

5.verse: They said to the king, "As for the man who was exterminating us and who intended to destroy us that we might have no place in all the territory of Israel,

6.verse: let seven men from among his descendants be given to us, that we may dismember them before the LORD in Gibeon, on the LORD'S mountain." The king replied, "I will give them up."

7.verse: The king, however, spared Meribbaal, son of Jonathan, son of Saul, because of the LORD'S oath that formed a bond between David and Saul's son Jonathan.

8.verse: But the king took Armoni and Meribbaal, the two sons that Aiah's daughter Rizpah had borne to Saul, and the five sons of Saul's daughter Merob that she had borne to Adriel, son of Barzillai the Meholathite,

9.verse: and surrendered them to the Gibeonites. They then dismembered them on the mountain before the LORD. The seven fell at the one time; they were put to death during the first days of the harvest - that is, at the beginning of the barley harvest.

10.verse: Then Rizpah, Aiah's daughter, took sackcloth and spread it out for herself on the rock from the beginning of the harvest until rain came down on them from the sky, fending off the birds of the sky from settling on them by day, and the wild animals by night.

11.verse: When David was informed of what Rizpah, Aiah's daughter, the concubine of Saul, had done,

12.verse: he went and obtained the bones of Saul and of his son Jonathan from the citizens of Jabesh-gilead, who had carried them off secretly from the public square of Beth-shan, where the Philistines had hanged them at the time they killed Saul on Gilboa.

13.verse: When he had brought up from there the bones of Saul and of his son Jonathan, the bones of those who had been dismembered were also gathered up.

14.verse: Then the bones of Saul and of his son Jonathan were buried in the tomb of his father Kish at Zela in the territory of Benjamin. After all that the king commanded had been carried out, God granted relief to the land.

15.verse: There was another battle between the Philistines and Israel. David went down with his servants and fought the Philistines, but David grew tired.

16.verse: Dadu, one of the Rephaim, whose bronze spear weighed three hundred shekels, was about to take him captive. Dadu was girt with a new sword and planned to kill David,

17.verse: but Abishai, son of Zeruiah, came to his assistance and struck and killed the Philistine. Then David's men swore to him, "You must not go out to battle with us again, lest you quench the lamp of Israel."

18.verse: After this there was another battle with the Philistines in Gob. On that occasion Sibbecai, from Husha, killed Saph, one of the Rephaim.

19.verse: There was another battle with the Philistines in Gob, in which Elhanan, son of Jair from Bethlehem, killed Goliath of Gath, who had a spear with a shaft like a weaver's heddle-bar.

20.verse: There was another battle at Gath in which there was a man of large stature with six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot - twenty-four in all. He too was one of the Rephaim.

21.verse: And when he insulted Israel, Jonathan, son of David's brother Shimei, killed him.

22.verse: These four were Rephaim in Gath, and they fell at the hands of David and his servants.

1.verse: The king was shaken, and went up to the room over the city gate to weep. He said as he wept, "My son Absalom! My son, my son Absalom! If only I had died instead of you, Absalom, my son, my son!"

2.verse: Joab was told that the king was weeping and mourning for Absalom;

3.verse: and that day's victory was turned into mourning for the whole army when they heard that the king was grieving for his son.

4.verse: The soldiers stole into the city that day like men shamed by flight in battle.

5.verse: Meanwhile the king covered his face and cried out in a loud voice, "My son Absalom! Absalom! My son, my son!"

6.verse: Then Joab went to his residence and said: "Though they saved your life and your sons' and daughters' lives, also the lives of your wives and those of your concubines, you have put all your servants to shame today

7.verse: by loving those who hate you and hating those who love you. For you have shown today that officers and servants mean nothing to you. Indeed I am now certain that if Absalom were alive today and all of us dead, you would think that more suitable.

8.verse: Now then, get up! Go out and speak kindly to your servants. I swear by the LORD that if you do not go out, not a single man will remain with you overnight, and this will be a far greater disaster for you than any that has afflicted you from your youth until now."

9.verse: So the king stepped out and sat at the gate. When all the people were informed that the king was sitting at the gate, they came into his presence. Now the Israelites had fled to their separate tents,

10.verse: but throughout the tribes of Israel all the people were arguing among themselves, saying to one another: "The king delivered us from the clutches of our enemies, and it was he who rescued us from the grip of the Philistines. But now he has fled from the country before Absalom,

11.verse: and Absalom, whom we anointed over us, died in battle. Why, then, should you remain silent about restoring the king to his palace?" When the talk of all Israel reached the king,

12.verse: David sent word to the priests Zadok and Abiathar: "Say to the elders of Judah: 'Why should you be last to restore the king to his palace?

13.verse: You are my brothers, you are my bone and flesh. Why should you be last to restore the king?'

14.verse: Also say to Amasa: 'Are you not my bone and flesh? May God do thus and so to me, if you do not become my general permanently in place of Joab.'"

15.verse: He won over all the Judahites as one man, and so they summoned the king to return, with all his servants.

16.verse: When the king, on his return, reached the Jordan, Judah had come to Gilgal to meet him and to escort him across the Jordan.

17.verse: Shimei, son of Gera, the Benjaminite from Bahurim, hurried down with the Judahites to meet King David,

18.verse: accompanied by a thousand men from Benjamin. Ziba, too, the servant of the house of Saul, accompanied by his fifteen sons and twenty servants, hastened to the Jordan before the king.

19.verse: They crossed over the ford to bring the king's household over and to do whatever he wished. When Shimei, son of Gera, crossed the Jordan, he fell down before the king

20.verse: and said to him: "May my lord not hold me guilty, and may he not remember and take to heart the wrong that your servant did the day my lord the king left Jerusalem.

21.verse: For your servant knows that he has done wrong. Yet realize that I have been the first of the whole house of Joseph to come down today to meet my lord the king."

22.verse: But Abishai, son of Zeruiah, countered: "Shimei must be put to death for this. He cursed the LORD'S anointed."

23.verse: David replied: "What has come between you and me, sons of Zeruiah, that you would create enmity for me this day? Should anyone die today in Israel? Am I not aware that today I am king of Israel?"

24.verse: Then the king said to Shimei, "You shall not die." And the king gave him his oath.

25.verse: Meribbaal, son of Saul, also went down to meet the king. He had not washed his feet nor trimmed his mustache nor washed his clothes from the day the king left until he returned safely.

26.verse: When he came from Jerusalem to meet the king, the king asked him, "Why did you not go with me, Meribbaal?"

27.verse: He replied: "My lord the king, my servant betrayed me. For your servant, who is lame, said to him, 'Saddle the ass for me, that I may ride on it and go with the king.'

28.verse: But he slandered your servant before my lord the king. But my lord the king is like an angel of God. Do what you judge best.

29.verse: For though my father's entire house deserved only death from my lord the king, yet you placed your servant among the guests at your table. What right do I still have to make further appeal to the king?"

30.verse: But the king said to him: "Why do you go on talking? I say, 'You and Ziba shall divide the property.'"

31.verse: Meribbaal answered the king, "Indeed let him have it all, now that my lord the king has returned safely to his palace."

32.verse: Barzillai the Gileadite also came down from Rogelim and escorted the king to the Jordan for his crossing, taking leave of him there.

33.verse: It was Barzillai, a very old man of eighty and very wealthy besides, who had provisioned the king during his stay in Mahanaim.

34.verse: The king said to Barzillai, "Cross over with me, and I will provide for your old age as my guest in Jerusalem."

35.verse: But Barzillai answered the king: "How much longer have I to live, that I should go up to Jerusalem with the king?

36.verse: I am now eighty years old. Can I distinguish between good and bad? Can your servant taste what he eats and drinks, or still appreciate the voices of singers and songstresses? Why should your servant be any further burden to my lord the king?

37.verse: In escorting the king across the Jordan, your servant is doing little enough! Why should the king give me this reward?

38.verse: Please let your servant go back to die in his own city by the tomb of his father and mother. Here is your servant Chimham. Let him cross over with my lord the king. Do for him whatever you will."

39.verse: Then the king said to him, "Chimham shall come over with me, and I will do for him as you would wish. And anything else you would like me to do for you, I will do."

40.verse: Then all the people crossed over the Jordan but the king remained; he kissed Barzillai and bade him Godspeed as he returned to his own district.

41.verse: Finally the king crossed over to Gilgal, accompanied by Chimham. All the people of Judah and half of the people of Israel had escorted the king across.

42.verse: But all these Israelites began coming to the king and saying, "Why did our brothers the Judahites steal you away and escort the king and his household across the Jordan, along with all David's men?"

43.verse: All the Judahites replied to the men of Israel: "Because the king is our relative. Why are you angry over this affair? Have we had anything to eat at the king's expense? Or have portions from his table been given to us?"

44.verse: The Israelites answered the Judahites: "We have ten shares in the king. Also, we are the first-born rather than you. Why do you slight us? Were we not first to speak of restoring the king?" Then the Judahites in turn spoke even more fiercely than the Israelites.

1.verse: After this David inquired of the LORD, "Shall I go up into one of the cities of Judah?" The LORD replied to him, "Yes." Then David asked, "Where shall I go?" He replied, "To Hebron."

2.verse: So David went up there accompanied by his two wives, Ahinoam of Jezreel and Abigail, the widow of Nabal of Carmel.

3.verse: David also brought up his men with their families, and they dwelt in the cities near Hebron.

4.verse: Then the men of Judah came there and anointed David king of the Judahites.A report reached David that the men of Jabesh-gilead had buried Saul.

5.verse: So David sent messengers to the men of Jabesh-gilead and said to them: "May you be blessed by the LORD for having done this kindness to your lord Saul in burying him.

6.verse: And now may the LORD be kind and faithful to you. I, too, will be generous to you for having done this.

7.verse: Take courage, therefore, and prove yourselves valiant men, for though your lord Saul is dead, the Judahites have anointed me their king."

8.verse: Abner, son of Ner, Saul's general, took Ishbaal, son of Saul, and brought him over to Mahanaim,

9.verse: where he made him king over Gilead, the Ashurites, Jezreel, Ephraim, Benjamin, and the rest of Israel.

10.verse: Ishbaal, son of Saul, was forty years old when he became king over Israel, and he reigned for two years. The Judahites alone followed David.

11.verse: In all, David spent seven years and six months in Hebron as king of the Judahites.

12.verse: Now Abner, son of Ner, and the servants of Ishbaal, Saul's son, left Mahanaim for Gibeon.

13.verse: Joab, son of Zeruiah, and David's servants also set out and met them at the pool of Gibeon. And they sat down, one group on one side of the pool and the other on the opposite side.

14.verse: Then Abner said to Joab, "Let the young men rise and perform for us." Joab replied, "All right!"

15.verse: So they rose and were counted off: twelve of the Benjaminites of Ishbaal, son of Saul, and twelve of David's servants.

16.verse: Then each one grasped his opponent's head and thrust his sword into his opponent's side, and all fell down together. And so that place, which is in Gideon, was named the Field of the Sides.

17.verse: After a very fierce battle that day, Abner and the men of Israel were defeated by David's servants.

18.verse: The three sons of Zeruiah were there-Joab, Abishai, and Asahel. Asahel, who was as fleet of foot as a gazelle in the open field,

19.verse: set out after Abner, turning neither right nor left in his pursuit.

20.verse: Abner turned around and said, "Is that you, Asahel?" He replied, "Yes."

21.verse: Abner said to him, "Turn right or left; seize one of the young men and take what you can strip from him." But Asahel would not desist from his pursuit.

22.verse: Once more Abner said to Asahel: "Stop pursuing me! Why must I strike you to the ground? How could I face your brother Joab?"

23.verse: Still he refused to stop. So Abner struck him in the abdomen with the heel of his javelin, and the weapon protruded from his back. He fell there and died on the spot. And all who came to the place where Asahel had fallen and died, came to a halt.

24.verse: Joab and Abishai, however, continued the pursuit of Abner. The sun had gone down when they came to the hill of Ammah which lies east of the valley toward the desert near Geba.

25.verse: Here the Benjaminites rallied around Abner, forming a single group, and made a stand on the hilltop.

26.verse: Then Abner called to Joab and said: "Must the sword destroy to the utmost? Do you not know that afterward there will be bitterness? How much longer will you refrain from ordering the people to stop the pursuit of their brothers?"

27.verse: Joab replied, "As God lives, if you had not spoken, the soldiers would not have been withdrawn from the pursuit of their brothers until morning."

28.verse: Joab then sounded the horn, and all the soldiers came to a halt, pursuing Israel no farther and fighting no more.

29.verse: Abner and his men marched all night long through the Arabah, crossed the Jordan, marched all through the morning, and came to Mahanaim.

30.verse: Joab, after interrupting the pursuit of Abner, assembled all the men. Besides Asahel, nineteen other servants of David were missing.

31.verse: But David's servants had fatally wounded three hundred and sixty men of Benjamin, followers of Abner.

32.verse: They took up Asahel and buried him in his father's tomb in Bethlehem. Joab and his men made an all-night march, and dawn found them in Hebron.

1.verse: The LORD'S anger against Israel flared again, and he incited David against the Israelites by prompting him to number Israel and Judah.

2.verse: Accordingly the king said to Joab and the leaders of the army who were with him, "Tour all the tribes in Israel from Dan to Beer-sheba and register the people, that I may know their number."

3.verse: But Joab said to the king: "May the LORD your God increase the number of people a hundredfold for your royal majesty to see it with his own eyes. But why does it please my lord the king to order a thing of this kind?"

4.verse: The king, however, overruled Joab and the leaders of the army, so they left the king's presence in order to register the people of Israel.

5.verse: Crossing the Jordan, they began near Aroer, south of the city in the wadi, and went in the direction of Gad toward Jazer.

6.verse: They continued on to Gilead and to the district below Mount Hermon. Then they proceeded to Dan; from there they turned toward Sidon,

7.verse: going to the fortress of Tyre and to all the cities of the Hivites and Canaanites, and ending up at Beer-sheba in the Negeb of Judah.

8.verse: Thus they toured the whole country, reaching Jerusalem again after nine months and twenty days.

9.verse: Joab then reported to the king the number of people registered: in Israel, eight hundred thousand men fit for military service; in Judah, five hundred thousand.

10.verse: Afterward, however, David regretted having numbered the people, and said to the LORD: "I have sinned grievously in what I have done. But now, LORD, forgive the guilt of your servant, for I have been very foolish."

11.verse: When David rose in the morning, the LORD had spoken to the prophet Gad, David's seer, saying:

12.verse: "Go and say to David, 'This is what the LORD says: I offer you three alternatives; choose one of them, and I will inflict it on you.'"

13.verse: Gad then went to David to inform him. He asked: "Do you want a three years' famine to come upon your land, or to flee from your enemy three months while he pursues you, or to have a three days' pestilence in your land? Now consider and decide what I must reply to him who sent me."

14.verse: David answered Gad: "I am in very serious difficulty. Let us fall by the hand of God, for he is most merciful; but let me not fall by the hand of man."

15.verse: Thus David chose the pestilence. Now it was the time of the wheat harvest when the plague broke out among the people. (The LORD then sent a pestilence over Israel from morning until the time appointed, and seventy thousand of the people from Dan to Beer-sheba died.)

16.verse: But when the angel stretched forth his hand toward Jerusalem to destroy it, the LORD regretted the calamity and said to the angel causing the destruction among the people, "Enough now! Stay your hand." The angel of the LORD was then standing at the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.

17.verse: When David saw the angel who was striking the people, he said to the LORD: "It is I who have sinned; it is I, the shepherd, who have done wrong. But these are sheep; what have they done? Punish me and my kindred."

18.verse: On the same day Gad went to David and said to him, "Go up and build an altar to the LORD on the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite."

19.verse: Following Gad's bidding, David went up as the LORD had commanded.

20.verse: Now Araunah looked down and noticed the king and his servants coming toward him while he was threshing wheat. So he went out and paid homage to the king, with face to the ground.

21.verse: Then Araunah asked, "Why does my lord the king come to his servant?" David replied, "To buy the threshing floor from you, to build an altar to the LORD, that the plague may be checked among the people."

22.verse: But Araunah said to David: "Let my lord the king take and offer up whatever he may wish. Here are oxen for holocausts, and threshing sledges and the yokes of the oxen for wood.

23.verse: All this does Araunah give to the king." Araunah then said to the king, "May the LORD your God accept your offering."

24.verse: The king, however, replied to Araunah, "No, I must pay you for it, for I cannot offer to the LORD my God holocausts that cost nothing." So David bought the threshing floor and the oxen for fifty silver shekels.

25.verse: Then David built an altar there to the LORD, and offered holocausts and peace offerings. The LORD granted relief to the country, and the plague was checked in Israel.

1.verse: When Joab, son of Zeruiah, observed how the king felt toward Absalom,

2.verse: he sent to Tekoa and brought from there a gifted woman, to whom he said: "Pretend to be in mourning. Put on mourning apparel and do not anoint yourself with oil, that you may appear to be a woman who has been long in mourning for a departed one.

3.verse: Then go to the king and speak to him in this manner." And Joab instructed her what to say.

4.verse: So the woman of Tekoa went to the king and fell prostrate to the ground in homage, saying, "Help, your majesty!"

5.verse: The king said to her, "What do you want?" She replied: "Alas, I am a widow; my husband is dead.

6.verse: Your servant had two sons, who quarreled in the field. There being no one to part them, one of them struck his brother and killed him.

7.verse: Then the whole clan confronted your servant and demanded: 'Give up the one who killed his brother. We must put him to death for the life of his brother whom he has slain; we must extinguish the heir also.' Thus they will quench my remaining hope and leave my husband neither name nor posterity upon the earth."

8.verse: The king then said to the woman: "Go home. I will issue a command on your behalf."

9.verse: The woman of Tekoa answered him, "Let me and my family be to blame, my lord king; you and your throne are innocent."

10.verse: Then the king said, "If anyone says a word to you, have him brought to me, and he shall not touch you again."

11.verse: But she went on to say, "Please, your majesty, keep in mind the LORD your God, that the avenger of blood may not go too far in destruction and that my son may not be done away with." He replied, "As the LORD lives, not a hair of your son shall fall to the ground."

12.verse: The woman continued, "Please let your servant say still another word to my lord the king." He replied, "Speak."

13.verse: So the woman said: "Why, then, do you think of this same kind of thing against the people of God? In pronouncing as he has, the king shows himself guilty, for not bringing back his own banished son.

14.verse: We must indeed die; we are then like water that is poured out on the ground and cannot be gathered up. Yet, though God does not bring back life, he does take thought how not to banish anyone from him.

15.verse: And now, if I have presumed to speak of this matter to your majesty, it is because the people have given me cause to fear. And so your servant thought: 'Let me speak to the king. Perhaps he will grant the petition of his maidservant.

16.verse: For the king must surely consent to free his servant from the grasp of one who would seek to destroy me and my son as well from God's inheritance.'"

17.verse: And the woman concluded: "Let the word of my lord the king provide a resting place; indeed, my lord the king is like an angel of God, evaluating good and bad. The LORD your God be with you."

18.verse: The king answered the woman, "Now do not conceal from me anything I may ask you!" The woman said, "Let my lord the king speak."

19.verse: So the king asked, "Is Joab involved with you in all this?" And the woman answered: "As you live, my lord the king, it is just as your majesty has said, and not otherwise. It was your servant Joab who instructed me and told your servant all these things she was to say.

20.verse: Your servant Joab did this to come at the issue in a roundabout way. But my lord is as wise as an angel of God, so that he knows all things on earth."

21.verse: Then the king said to Joab: "I hereby grant this request. Go, therefore, and bring back young Absalom."

22.verse: Falling prostrate to the ground in homage and blessing the king, Joab said, "This day I know that I am in good favor with you, my lord the king, since the king has granted the request of his servant."

23.verse: Joab then went off to Geshur and brought Absalom to Jerusalem.

24.verse: But the king said, "Let him go to his own house; he shall not appear before me." So Absalom went off to his house and did not appear before the king.

25.verse: In all Israel there was not a man who could so be praised for his beauty as Absalom, who was without blemish from the sole of his foot to the crown of his head.

26.verse: When he shaved his head - which he used to do at the end of every year, because his hair became too heavy for him - the hair weighed two hundred shekels according to the royal standard.

27.verse: Absalom had three sons born to him, besides a daughter named Tamar, who was a beautiful woman.

28.verse: Absalom lived in Jerusalem for two years without appearing before the king.

29.verse: Then he summoned Joab to send him to the king, but Joab would not come to him. Although he summoned him a second time, Joab refused to come.

30.verse: He therefore instructed his servants: "You see Joab's field that borders mine, on which he has barley. Go, set it on fire." And so Absalom's servants set the field on fire. Joab's farmhands came to him with torn garments and reported to him what had been done.

31.verse: At this, Joab went to Absalom in his house and asked him, "Why have your servants set my field on fire?"

32.verse: Absalom answered Joab: "I was summoning you to come here, that I may send you to the king to say: 'Why did I come back from Geshur? I would be better off if I were still there!' Now, let me appear before the king. If I am guilty, let him put me to death."

33.verse: Joab went to the king and reported this. The king then called Absalom, who came to him and in homage fell on his face to the ground before the king. Then the king kissed him.

annotations.2: [14] How not to banish: a possible allusion to the religious institution of cities of refuge for involuntary murderers; see Numbers 35:9-1

1.verse: After this David attacked the Philistines and conquered them, wresting. . . from the Philistines.

2.verse: He also defeated Moab and then measured them with a line, making them lie down on the ground. He told off two lengths of line for execution, and a full length to be spared. Thus the Moabites became tributary to David.

3.verse: Next David defeated Hadadezer, son of Rehob, king of Zobah, when he went to reestablish his dominion at the Euphrates River.

4.verse: David captured from him one thousand seven hundred horsemen and twenty thousand foot soldiers. And he hamstrung all the chariot horses, preserving only enough for a hundred chariots.

5.verse: When the Arameans of Damascus came to the aid of Hadadezer, king of Zobah, David slew twenty-two thousand of them.

6.verse: David then placed garrisons in Aram of Damascus, and the Arameans became subjects, tributary to David. The LORD brought David victory in all his undertakings.

7.verse: David also took away the golden shields used by Hadadezer's servants and brought them to Jerusalem. (These Shishak, king of Egypt, took away when he came to Jerusalem in the days of Rehoboam, son of Solomon.)

8.verse: From Tebah and Berothai, towns of Hadadezer, King David removed a very large quantity of bronze.

9.verse: When Toi, king of Hamath, heard that David had defeated all the forces of Hadadezer,

10.verse: he sent his son Hadoram to King David to greet him and to congratulate him for his victory over Hadadezer in battle, because Toi had been in many battles with Hadadezer. Hadoram also brought with him articles of silver, gold, and bronze.

11.verse: These, too, King David consecrated to the LORD, together with the silver and gold he had taken from every nation he had conquered:

12.verse: from Edom and Moab, from the Ammonites, from the Philistines, from the Amalekites, and from the plunder of Hadadezer, son of Rehob, king of Zobah.

13.verse: On his return, David became famous for having slain eighteen thousand Edomites in the Salt Valley;

14.verse: after which he placed garrisons in Edom. Thus all the Edomites became David's subjects, and the LORD brought David victory in all his undertakings.

15.verse: David reigned over all Israel, judging and administering justice to all his people.

16.verse: Joab, son of Zeruiah, was in command of the army. Jehoshaphat, son of Ahilud, was chancellor.

17.verse: Zadok, son of Ahitub, and Ahimelech, son of Abiathar, were priests. Shawsha was scribe.

18.verse: Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, was in command of the Cherethites and Pelethites. And David's sons were priests.
