1.verse: These are the last words of David: "The utterance of David, son of Jesse; the utterance of the man God raised up, Anointed of the God of Jacob, favorite of the Mighty One of Israel.

2.verse: The spirit of the LORD spoke through me; his word was on my tongue.

3.verse: The God of Israel spoke; of me the Rock of Israel said, 'He that rules over men in justice, that rules in the fear of God,

4.verse: Is like the morning light at sunrise on a cloudless morning, making the greensward sparkle after rain.'

5.verse: Is not my house firm before God? He has made an eternal covenant with me, set forth in detail and secured. Will he not bring to fruition all my salvation and my every desire?

6.verse: But the wicked are all like thorns to be cast away; they cannot be taken up by hand.

7.verse: He who wishes to touch them must arm himself with iron and the shaft of a spear, and they must be consumed by fire."

8.verse: These are the names of David's warriors. Ishbaal, son of Hachamoni, was the first of the Three. It was he who brandished his battle-ax over eight hundred slain in a single encounter.

9.verse: Next to him, among the Three warriors, was Eleazar, son of Dodo the Ahohite. He was with David at Ephes-dammim when the Philistines assembled there for battle. The Israelites had retreated,

10.verse: but he stood his ground and fought the Philistines until his hand grew tired and became cramped, holding fast to the sword. The LORD brought about a great victory on that day; the soldiers turned back after Eleazar, but only to strip the slain.

11.verse: Next to him was Shammah, son of Agee the Hararite. The Philistines had assembled at Lehi, where there was a plot of land full of lentils. When the soldiers fled from the Philistines,

12.verse: he took his stand in the middle of the plot and defended it. He slew the Philistines, and the LORD brought about a great victory. Such were the deeds of the Three warriors.

13.verse: During the harvest three of the Thirty went down to David in the cave of Adullam, while a Philistine clan was encamped in the Vale of Rephaim.

14.verse: At that time David was in the refuge, and there was a garrison of Philistines in Bethlehem.

15.verse: Now David had a strong craving and said, "Oh, that someone would give me a drink of water from the cistern that is by the gate of Bethlehem!"

16.verse: So the Three warriors broke through the Philistine camp and drew water from the cistern that is by the gate of Bethlehem. But when they brought it to David he refused to drink it, and instead poured it out to the LORD,

17.verse: saying: "The LORD forbid that I do this! Can I drink the blood of these men who went at the risk of their lives?" So he refused to drink it.

18.verse: Abishai, brother of Joab, son of Zeruiah, was at the head of the Thirty. It was he who brandished his spear over three hundred slain. He was listed among the Thirty

19.verse: and commanded greater respect than the Thirty, becoming their leader. However, he did not attain to the Three.

20.verse: Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, a stalwart from Kabzeel, was a man of great achievements. It was he who slew the two lions in Moab. He also went down and killed the lion in the cistern at the time of the snow.

21.verse: It was he, too, who slew an Egyptian of large stature. Although the Egyptian was armed with a spear, he went against him with a club and wrested the spear from the Egyptian's hand, then killed him with his own spear.

22.verse: Such were the deeds performed by Benaiah, son of Jehoiada. He was listed among the Thirty warriors

23.verse: and commanded greater respect than the Thirty. However, he did not attain to the Three. David put him in command of his bodyguard.

24.verse: Asahel, brother of Joab. . . .Among the Thirty were: Elhanan, son of Dodo, from Bethlehem;

25.verse: Shammah from En-harod; Elika from En-harod;

26.verse: Helez from Beth-pelet; Ira, son of Ikkesh, from Tekoa;

27.verse: Abiezer from Anathoth; Sibbecai from Hushah;

28.verse: Zalmon from Ahoh; Maharai from Netophah;

29.verse: Heled, son of Baanah, from Netophah; Ittai, son of Ribai, from Gibeah of the Benjaminites;

30.verse: Benaiah from Pirathon; Hiddai from Nahale-gaash;

31.verse: Abibaal from Beth-arabah; Azmaveth from Bahurim;

32.verse: Eliahba from Shaalbon; Jashen the Gunite; Jonathan,

33.verse: son of Shammah the Hararite; Ahiam, son of Sharar the Hararite;

34.verse: Eliphelet, son of Ahasbai, from Beth-maacah; Eliam, son of Ahithophel, from Gilo;

35.verse: Hezrai from Carmel; Paarai the Arbite;

36.verse: Igal, son of Nathan, from Zobah; Bani the Gadite;

37.verse: Zelek the Ammonite; Naharai from Beeroth, armor-bearer of Joab, son of Zeruiah;

38.verse: Ira from Jattir; Gareb from Jattir;

annotations.1: [1-7] The text of this short composition in the spirit of the wisdom writers ( Proverb 30:1-6) is difficult in places; it views David's career in retrospect.
annotations.2: [8-10] There are thirty-seven warriors in all mentioned in this list. First there are the Three warriors most noted for single-handed exploits ( 2 Sam 23:8-12). Then comes the story of a daring adventure by three unnamed members of the larger group ( 2 Sam 23:13-17). Next come the commanders of the king's bodyguard, Abishai ( 2 Sam 23:18-19) and Benaiah ( 2 Sam 23:20-23), with whom must be counted Asahel ( 2 Sam 23:24) and Joab ( 2 Sam 23:18, 24, 37), and finally the group of the Thirty ( 2 Sam 23:24-39)
annotations.3: [24] A more complete notice about Asahel, who died early in his career ( 2 Sam 2:16-23), is to be presumed lost at this point. Elhanan is the first of the Thirty

1.verse: After mustering the troops he had with him, David placed officers in command of groups of a thousand and groups of a hundred.

2.verse: David then put a third part of the soldiers under Joab's command, a third under command of Abishai, son of Zeruiah and brother of Joab, and a third under command of Ittai the Gittite. The king then said to the soldiers, "I intend to go out with you myself."

3.verse: But they replied: "You must not come out with us. For if we should flee, we shall not count; even if half of us should die, we shall not count. You are equal to ten thousand of us. Therefore it is better that we have you to help us from the city."

4.verse: So the king said to them, "I will do what you think best"; and he stood by the gate as all the soldiers marched out in units of a hundred and of a thousand.

5.verse: But the king gave this command to Joab, Abishai and Ittai: "Be gentle with young Absalom for my sake." All the soldiers heard the king instruct the various leaders with regard to Absalom.

6.verse: David's army then took the field against Israel, and a battle was fought in the forest near Mahanaim.

7.verse: The forces of Israel were defeated by David's servants, and the casualties there that day were heavy - twenty thousand men.

8.verse: The battle spread out over that entire region, and the thickets consumed more combatants that day than did the sword.

9.verse: Absalom unexpectedly came up against David's servants. He was mounted on a mule, and, as the mule passed under the branches of a large terebinth, his hair caught fast in the tree. He hung between heaven and earth while the mule he had been riding ran off.

10.verse: Someone saw this and reported to Joab that he had seen Absalom hanging from a terebinth.

11.verse: Joab said to his informant: "If you saw him, why did you not strike him to the ground on the spot? Then it would have been my duty to give you fifty pieces of silver and a belt."

12.verse: But the man replied to Joab: "Even if I already held a thousand pieces of silver in my two hands, I would not harm the king's son, for the king charged you and Abishai and Ittai in our hearing to protect the youth Absalom for his sake.

13.verse: Had I been disloyal and killed him, the whole matter would have come to the attention of the king, and you would stand aloof."

14.verse: Joab replied, "I will not waste time with you in this way." And taking three pikes in hand, he thrust for the heart of Absalom, still hanging from the tree alive.

15.verse: Next, ten of Joab's young armor-bearers closed in on Absalom, and killed him with further blows.

16.verse: Joab then sounded the horn, and the soldiers turned back from the pursuit of the Israelites, because Joab called on them to halt.

17.verse: Absalom was taken up and cast into a deep pit in the forest, and a very large mound of stones was erected over him. And all the Israelites fled to their own tents.

18.verse: During his lifetime Absalom had taken a pillar and erected it for himself in the King's Valley, for he said, "I have no son to perpetuate my name." The pillar which he named for himself is called Yadabshalom to the present day.

19.verse: Then Ahimaaz, son of Zadok, said, "Let me run to take the good news to the king that the LORD has set him free from the grasp of his enemies."

20.verse: But Joab said to him: "You are not the man to bring the news today. On some other day you may take the good news, but today you would not be bringing good news, for in fact the king's son is dead."

21.verse: Then Joab said to a Cushite, "Go, tell the king what you have seen." The Cushite bowed to Joab and sped away.

22.verse: But Ahimaaz, son of Zadok, said to Joab again, "Come what may, permit me also to run after the Cushite." Joab replied: "Why do you want to run, my son? You will receive no reward."

23.verse: But he insisted, "Come what may, I want to run." Joab said to him, "Very well." Ahimaaz sped off by way of the Jordan plain and outran the Cushite.

24.verse: Now David was sitting between the two gates, and a lookout mounted to the roof of the gate above the city wall, where he looked about and saw a man running all alone.

25.verse: The lookout shouted to inform the king, who said, "If he is alone, he has good news to report." As he kept coming nearer,

26.verse: the lookout spied another runner. From his place atop the gate he cried out, "There is another man running by himself." And the king responded, "He, too, is bringing good news."

27.verse: Then the lookout said, "I notice that the first one runs like Ahimaaz, son of Zadok." The king replied, "He is a good man; he comes with good news."

28.verse: Then Ahimaaz called out and greeted the king. With face to the ground he paid homage to the king and said, "Blessed be the LORD your God, who has delivered up the men who rebelled against my lord the king."

29.verse: But the king asked, "Is the youth Absalom safe?" And Ahimaaz replied, "I saw a great disturbance when the king's servant Joab sent your servant on, but I do not know what it was."

30.verse: The king said, "Step aside and remain in attendance here." So he stepped aside and remained there.

31.verse: When the Cushite came in, he said, "Let my lord the king receive the good news that this day the LORD has taken your part, freeing you from the grasp of all who rebelled against you."

32.verse: But the king asked the Cushite, "Is young Absalom safe?" The Cushite replied, "May the enemies of my lord the king and all who rebel against you with evil intent be as that young man!"
